articles.headline: Billionaires Can Seem Like Saviors to Media Companies, but They Come With Risks
articles.snippet: With many publications struggling, the largess of a wealthy owner can be welcome. But there are concerns that these buyers are assuming too much influence.
articles.abstract: With many publications struggling, the largess of a wealthy owner can be welcome. But there are concerns that these buyers are assuming too much influence.
articles.lead_paragraph: Roughly a century ago, men like William Randolph Hearst, Joseph Pulitzer and Henry Luce dominated the media landscape. These moguls built their publishing empires and used them to intimidate rivals, espouse favored causes and settle scores.

articles.headline: Inside Facebook’s Election ‘War Room’
articles.snippet: Seven weeks before the midterm elections, the social network is setting up a central hub to root out disinformation and false news. We visited the operation.
articles.abstract: Seven weeks before the midterm elections, the social network is setting up a central hub to root out disinformation and false news. We visited the operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — Sandwiched between Building 20 and Building 21 in the heart of Facebook’s campus, an approximately 25-foot-by-35-foot conference room is under construction.
articles.byline: By Sheera Frenkel and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: For Christine Blasey Ford, a Drastic Turn From a Quiet Life in Academia
articles.snippet: Dr. Blasey, a researcher and statistician, was reluctant to come forward with her allegation that Brett Kavanaugh, President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee, sexually assaulted her.
articles.abstract: Dr. Blasey, a researcher and statistician, was reluctant to come forward with her allegation that Brett Kavanaugh, President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee, sexually assaulted her.
articles.lead_paragraph: The text message from Christine Blasey Ford this summer worried her college best friend, Catherine Piwowarski.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Williamson, Rebecca R. Ruiz, Emily Steel, Grace Ashford and Steve Eder

articles.headline: They Were Seeking Mental Health Care. Instead They Drowned in a Sheriff’s Van.
articles.snippet: After two women voluntarily went to hospitals seeking care, they were committed and transported in a sheriff’s van that drove onto a flooded road.
articles.abstract: After two women voluntarily went to hospitals seeking care, they were committed and transported in a sheriff’s van that drove onto a flooded road.
articles.lead_paragraph: MULLINS, S.C. — Nicolette Green had decided to get better. The medication she was taking to treat her schizophrenia had calmed her and cleared her head. On Tuesday morning, her oldest daughter, Rose, with whom she had spent the weekend waiting out Hurricane Florence, drove her to her regular counseling session.
articles.byline: By Tyler Pager, Campbell Robertson and Chris Dixon

articles.headline: ‘Suicider!’ Came the Warning. For Afghans, Wrestlers’ Deaths Resound.
articles.snippet: The Islamic State killed as many as 30 Afghan wrestlers in a suicide bombing at their gym. The survivors blame the government, too. Now they are rebuilding.
articles.abstract: The Islamic State killed as many as 30 Afghan wrestlers in a suicide bombing at their gym. The survivors blame the government, too. Now they are rebuilding.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — There is a saying here: “A wrestler never dies.” It’s a commentary on how the sport’s champions hold a special place in Afghan hearts, and over the years, no place has produced more winners than the Maiwand Wrestling Club in Kabul.
articles.byline: By Rod Nordland and Fatima Faizi

articles.headline: The Netherlands, a Tax Avoidance Center, Tries to Mend Its Ways
articles.snippet: The country has a reputation for allowing multinationals to reduce payments by moving profits through Dutch subsidiaries, but things could be changing.
articles.abstract: The country has a reputation for allowing multinationals to reduce payments by moving profits through Dutch subsidiaries, but things could be changing.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — The Netherlands wants you to know that it is not a tax haven. But Menno Snel, the country’s No. 2 finance official, grudgingly acknowledges that the Dutch have become experts at something else: aggressive tax planning.

articles.headline: Evangelical Leaders Are Frustrated at G.O.P. Caution on Kavanaugh Allegation
articles.snippet: They say religious conservatives may feel little motivation to vote in the November elections unless Senate Republicans defend and confirm Judge Kavanaugh.
articles.abstract: They say religious conservatives may feel little motivation to vote in the November elections unless Senate Republicans defend and confirm Judge Kavanaugh.
articles.lead_paragraph: Worried their chance to cement a conservative majority on the Supreme Court could slip away, a growing number of evangelical and anti-abortion leaders are expressing frustration that Senate Republicans and the White House are not protecting Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh more forcefully from a sexual assault allegation and warning that conservative voters may stay home in November if his nomination falls apart.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Elizabeth Dias
